pdhp306:1: The one who has an exceeding lack of virtue, like a deadly creeper covering a Sal tree,
pdhp306:2: makes himself the same as his enemy wishes him to be.
pdhp307:1: That wickedness done by oneself, born in oneself, arising in oneself,
pdhp307:2: crushes the one who is stupid, as a diamond crushes a rock-jewel.
pdhp308:1: By oneself alone is a wicked deed done, by oneself is one defiled,
pdhp308:2: by oneself is a wicked deed left undone, by oneself is one purified,
pdhp308:3: purity and impurity come from oneself, for no one purify another.
pdhp309:1: Not the wrongs of others, or what others have done or have not done
pdhp309:2: one should consider, but what has been done and not done by oneself.
pdhp310:1: Not the wrongs of others, or what is just and unjust for others
pdhp310:2: one should consider, but what is just and unjust for oneself.
pdhp311:1: If one regards oneself as dear one should guard oneself right well,
pdhp311:2: for happiness is not easy to gain by those who do wrong.
pdhp312:1: If one regards oneself as dear one should guard oneself right well,
pdhp312:2: during one of the three watches of the night the wise one should stay alert.
pdhp313:1: Sitting alone, lying down alone, walking alone, diligent,
pdhp313:2: the solitary one who delights in himself will delight in the edge of a forest.
pdhp314:1: Whoever reviles the worthy teaching of the Noble Ones who live by Dhamma,
pdhp314:2: that stupid one, depending on wicked views,
pdhp314:3: makes himself the same as his enemy wishes him to be.
pdhp315:1: Whoever reviles the worthy teaching of the Noble Ones who live by Dhamma,
pdhp315:2: that stupid one, depending on wicked views,
pdhp315:3: like the bamboo when it bears fruit, brings about his own destruction.
pdhp316:1: First one should establish oneself in the good and the Dhamma,
pdhp316:2: then one can advise another, saying: ‘You must be as I am’.
pdhp317:1: First one should commit oneself to what is suitable,
pdhp317:2: then when advising another, the wise one should not have any defilement.
pdhp318:1: He should do himself as he would advise another to do,
pdhp318:2: being untrained, he should surely train himself, for it is said the self is difficult to train.
pdhp319:1: A tamed self is better than that of other people,
pdhp319:2: for the person who conquers himself, who lives always well-restrained,
pdhp320:1: neither gods, nor gandhabbas, nor Māra together with Brahmās,
pdhp320:2: can turn conquest into defeat for a person who is like this.
pdhp321:1: For the self is the friend of self, for what other friend would there be?
pdhp321:2: When the self is well-practiced, one finds a friend that is hard to find.
pdhp322:1: Self is the protector of self, self is the refuge of self,
pdhp322:2: therefore one should restrain oneself, as a merchant restrains his noble horse.
pdhp323:1: One should tame oneself always, that will be for a good destiny,
pdhp323:2: be tamed, be peaceful, be upright, and from that be honest,
pdhp323:3: then, tamed, be happy, unattached and cooled down.
pdhp324:1: By oneself one should censure self, by oneself one should be controlled,
pdhp324:2: he who guards himself, mindful, will live happily, monastic.
pdhp325:1: One should not neglect one’s own good for another’s, however great;
pdhp325:2: knowing further what is good for oneself should be the supreme good.
pdhp326:1: Not for one’s own sake and not for another’s sake, not desiring heaven, riches, or a kingdom—
pdhp326:2: he should not desire his success through corruption; he should be both virtuous and wise and righteous.
